reviewText: As a huge fan of the movie and Lego games in general, I got to say this entry into the Lego series by Traveller's Tales is one of the weaker ones. The game's campaign follows the movie closely and each level is based off a key scene from the movie, like Lego Lord of the Rings or Lego Star Wars. In those levels is a fun mix of puzzle solving and platforming using different characters with unique abilities. It's essentially what we've come to expect from all the Lego games up to this point. What makes this one different is that it's actually tying in with a new movie, not just based upon an old franchise. Fortunately, it's tying in with a movie about Legos, a perfect fit. But the syndrome of movie tie-in games rears it's ugly head into The Lego Movie Videogame. It feels more rushed than previous Lego games, like the designers are stretching out scenes in the movie to go on for a 20-30 minute level. It feels like they're padding the game out to be much longer than it should be, and that creates boredom. This reminds me of the Lego games on the Nintendo DS, where the levels are padded out with extremely repetitive puzzles and and button-mashy combat sequences. It's a shame too because I was really looking forward to this game. In terms of everything else, the music and graphics are fantastic and fit the style of the movie perfectly. This is one pretty looking game and is the first of the TT Lego games to be entirely made of Legos, so that's nice. Unfortunately, the core gameplay feels scaled back and TT just gave us the bare minimum, even the open world part of game is contained of small chunks instead of one big world. Really, the game is not bad, I would recommend it if you like the previous Lego games or really enjoyed the movie, it just isn't solid as previous Lego games.\n\nUPDATE 12/2/14 - I actually have grown a soft spot for the game so far. I still find Lego City Undercover and Lego Marvel better, but I love the source material so much that, it's hard for me to look at it as the weakest (Lego Indy 2 and Star Wars 3 are much worse), it gets better, trust me.

reviewText:
Ahh lego, who doesn't have a soft spot for it.
If you are new to the series don't let the appearance fool you. While the gameplay is simple in nature it's still very enjoyable for all age groups. Great blend of action and puzzles. Keeping to the tried and tested formula you swap between 2 or more characters (if playing solo). Each character will receive different costumes throughout the story, every costume changes the abilities you can use. Puzzles usually require use of all characters combining abilities to complete the task. Controls are simple and effective, though as with all lego games I would definitely recommend playing with a gamepad (or two).

Levels are a little shorter then some of the previous titles, but they do manage to fit a lot of action into each 'scene'. Upon completion you will unlock each of these for freeplay mode (open world). Length of the game gets extended quite a bit because as you progress through the game unlocking more characters, you can use these and return to past levels finding new areas and secrets you couldn't access earlier. Each level is a scene reenacted from the movie while cutscenes are copied directly from the movie itself, though they blend in well with the gameplay.

Graphically speaking it looks the part and performance is great overall. The artstyle helps a lot with the humour too which is classic tongue-in-cheek lego. Both adults and children should find it amusing on different levels. Game supports a range of video settings covering some higher end setups, eg, basic AA, 1440p+, 120hz+, DoF toggle etc.  (small note: at the time of writing you need to load into the game itself to change graphic options). No fps caps in place here either folks.

Voicework is top notch, all the official voice actors are used and I'm almost certain they managed to get some new lines written too.

Does make me sad each time a new lego game is released and it doesn't have online co-op support though. That would be the only small downside. Having played most of them now I can honestly say the last several have been brilliant. LOTR, Marvel and now The Lego Movie Videogame are all well worth picking up, particually if you have a children or friend nearby for some couch co-op. Solo play is a still an absolute blast, don't hear me wrong. ;)

reviewText:
By now you should know that if you've ever played a Lego game before that this new one brings nothing new to the table.

It focuses on the movie, which is great by the way, and it's split up in 15 missions. There's no true open world this time; there are hubs that can be freely explored with many of the characters, but they're not connected to each other. It isn't all that bad, but I can see why people don't like it this way. In fact, all the hubs could've been connected with a bit of creativity. Just sayin'.
The world is built entirely from Lego blocks which looks really cool. It fits the style of the movie perfectly.

The graphics are, again, the same as all the other Lego games; colorful and sharp. The game in general performs well, but there were a few times where the framerate dropped for a few seconds.
A big part of the sounds and music were also taken from the movie, including the catchy 'Everything is awesome' song.

As far as gameplay is concerned, there are a few new tricks. Building stuff with blueprints has potential, but isn't really all that fun. It needs more polish and people should be able to build stuff from scratch, instead of selecting the correct blocks. The master builder move looks great in motion and even though you don't really do anything it's still nice to do and watch.

About the missions. Each missions lasts about 15-45 minutes, and it can take much longer than that if you want to collect everything. Collecting everything will take you tens of hours. Finishing the game by just completing the missions will take you about 4-5 hours max. That's pretty short for a Lego game. I'm not the kind to collect and complete all things, but even I thought it was short in comparison to the other games. To be honest, I don't really mind. Every Lego game has the same gameplay and it's quickly wearing thin.

Give us something completely new, or add enough new stuff to make it special again. Special and fun, like Lego is supposed to be. In the meantime, this will do. Just don't play it before watching the movie first.

reviewText: If you are a fan of LEGO games, then you are probably going to love this. With a plot loosely based around The Matrix, it features some fantastic sequences, like a high-speed pursuit on a futuristic bike. As Wyldstyle (the female Trinity-esque protagonist) jumps from one vehicle to another while being pursued by the bad guys, it uses LEGO's two character co-op format brilliantly. Matrix 2, eat your hat! Early on though, a lot of the 'action' does involve building and demolition in the construction world. It's a clear nod to the real-world LEGO and you even have to seek out the instructions for the builds. These are identical to the type of instruction leaflets packed with real boxes of LEGO, on of many nice little touches to the game. I haven't watched the movie yet, but it's likely it pretty much recreates most of the scenes from the movie, as previous LEGO movie-tie-ins have. This time of course, with it being LEGO's very own product and movie, they have free reign to go nuts, throwing everything at you like a bucketload of trademarked plastic bricks. It also continues the trend of featuring humorous dialogue and sight gags. It's probably the funniest of all the LEGO games, and quite possibly the best. You rush through plenty of different themed LEGO worlds in the multiverse, donning some nifty apparel, which changes from location to location. There are as usual, plenty of characters to unlock, or purchase in the game. It doesn't really scream originality, with the usual tasks of collecting many, many hidden items  in an attempt to add replayability. It does pretty much what previous LEGO games have done before, but it does this very well, and is nicely graphically polished. Those who avoid LEGO games won't find much here to change their opinion. But fans will simply enjoy the ride. And the annoyingly catchy Everything is Awesome" song will be rolling around your head for days after.\n\n9/10"

reviewText:
This is one Lego-@ssLego game. I say that very deliberately. I love Lego games. I played every single one to 100% up until LoTR and have played a smattering to 100% since then.

Lego games are a blast. They're super formulaic. Destroy, build, run around collecting stuff and find hidden things. I love the cutesy sense of humor that these games bring to the table. Before the days when the Lego games included voice acting, there was such a great charm in the way the characters moved around to convey the mood. Despite voice acting, that is still there. This game is no different. They took a great movie and turned it into a full length lego game.

The HUB world is huge, but this game followed the LoTR and Harry Potter style of adding ghost coins to follow in order to know where to go. The vehicles handle beautifully. The character purchasing is done from a menu in this game instead of running around on a wild goose chase.

Now the bad: This IS a Lego-ey Lego game. Which means it will feel that no one ever beta tested it. When I played Lego Potter (1-4), I had a game breaking glitch. I restarted the game. I had a completely different game breaking glitch. Same That's the only Lego game I have ever played and not played to 100%. The bad news: While playing this, I have hit almost a dozen glitches and I have not even finished story mode yet. Cut scenes won't load, areas don't register so I can't enter them, it will show I have to kill enemies but none will spawn. Worst of all, when I save and exit the level, it doesn't remember my progress. The good news is these aren't game breaking problems (yet). Each time I find these issues, I quit out and the bug is gone the next time I play.

I recommend this game as a Lego game. It does exactly what you would expect from this style of game. It's light hearted, fun, charming and addictive. It is also incredibly glitchy, like most Lego games. Play this at your own risk!

reviewText:
BitzComms Reviews: The Lego Movie Video Game

(This review covers the PC - Your experience may differ from platform to platform)

I have to be honest with you - The Lego Movie came to me by complete surprise. For all the time I spend on YouTube, no word was spoken of the movie (at least that I saw) until I first saw the trailer for it on TV...

But then I was surprised even more when a video game was announced for it - It wasn't even a full year after Lego Marvel Super Heroes came out, and Traveller's Tales came out with a new game already?

It was more surprising that the game was coming to all major platforms, INCLUDING next gen platforms like the PS4, Xbox One, Wii U, in addition to the PC, Xbox 360 and PS3... Yikes.

The short development period between this and Marvel seemed like a sign that this game was going to blow HARD... But then I played it, and it is probably my favorite Traveller's Tales Lego game of all time.

STORY:

The game follows the story of the movie down pat... Which might turn off those who haven't seen it yet. I suggest you see the movie before you play the game, but even if you don't, the game doesn't feature EVERY scene from the movie... Some of the scenes that are in the game have parts that were cut from the movie, most likely to keep from spoiling the movie for those who haven't seen it. I won't explain the story itself, because we have a movie for that, and I wouldn't want to spoil anything.

PRESENTATION:

The Lego games that have been developed by Traveller's Tales over the years have had a reputation of exceptional presentation, and this one is no different. The game is fully voiced, and either they got the celebrity voices from the movie to do the game, or they just got really, really good sound-alikes. If it's the latter, I wouldn't be able to tell the difference because the acting in this game is so damn good. As I said before, the story is presented through scenes from the movie, and while that may sound kind of cheap, you have to keep in mind the short period between the release of this and Marvel. Plus, the scenes look so good already that you won't mind at all. It kind of harkens back to the days of movie tie-ins on the Playstation, which generally used scenes from the movie for the cutscenes of the game. Anyone remember Toy Story 2: Buzz Lightyear to the Rescue? (also developed by Traveller's Tales) The game also makes use of a new animation style - The characters actually move like actual lego... No more bendy, stretchy lego limbs. This is probably done to stay true to the stop-motion style of the movie.

GRAPHICS:

The game looks amazing, as everything is made of Lego this time around. The game also runs really well on low-end machines like mine, and that's always a plus.

SOUND:

Everything is Awesome!

GAMEPLAY:

Here's where things get pretty iffy - The game itself is a mixed bag. While this is my favorite TT Lego title so far, I can't deny this game has some serious problems. Let's first talk about the character selection - There are over NINETY characters... NINETY CHARACTERS. Don't get too excited though, as most of the characters are either clones of existing characters, or very minor characters that no one cares about. Most of the characters are different suits for Emmet. Wild Style or Unikitty. There are some good ones in this game, such as Lord Business, Metalbeard, Batman, Super Man, The Green Lantern, Wonder Woman and even the Green Ninja from Lego Ninjago.

Emmet himself is a pretty boring character as well. For the majority of the game, all he can really do is use instruction builds. He can't use master builds, and he doesn't have any interesting attacks or gimmicks. Most of the time, you'll be playing as Wild Style, Batman and Unikitty, switching to Emmet only when you need to use an instruction build. Eventually Emmet gets the ability to use Master Builds, but that's very late in the game.

Next, let's talk about the gameplay. The game follows the same basic formula as any other TT Lego title before it - Go through the levels, collecting studs and accomplishing objectives with preset characters, then go back and play those levels as any character to find hidden unlockables - Only this time it's mixed with free-roaming hub worlds, and my GOD these are underwhelming. Compared to Lego City: Undercover and especially Lego Marvel Super Heroes, these free-roaming segments seem to be just an after-thought. They are very small and contained. Not very much fun.

Next, let's talk about the levels for a minute. The levels are probably the best part of the game, with only a few stinkers here and there. The only problem is that many of them are very long, and when there's a bad level, there's a REALLY bad level. Each level is quite interesting, with its own gimmick and setpieces. There's an entire level that takes place on an under-constuction submarine that's careening down an ablaze Cloud Cuckoo Land. Many of the level designs are very inspired and smart, but they are quite long, and if you don't have a lot of time for one session, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. There are checkpoints placed around the levels that allow you to save your progress, but some of them are placed in areas where you really wouldn't notice them... oops.

THE VERDICT:

As a whole, however, The Lego Movie Video Game is quite solid, considering the short development period. There's a lot of content in here, and most of the levels are fun, if not a bit too long. I'm giving this game a 7.0 out of 10.

reviewText:
My favourite games from this series will always be the Original Trilogy episodes of the Star Wars games. There was something simple and charming about those games that will always appeal to me more than the quagmire that a few of the later games sunk into, in my opinion. I felt later games disappeared into a hole of fiddly complexity regarding character abilities and level design that sucked the fun out of playing.

In saying that, The Lego Movie: The Game rises above a lot of the others I've played, giving you multiple open-world hubs to play around in, as well as some entertaining levels that expand competently upon the movie's premise and retain the sense of fun and variety that Lego embodies as a product.

The voice acting is very good considering that the actors are mimicking the original stars, and it's rare that you feel like you're not ACTUALLY listening to the movie's actors.

My only sizable criticism comes from that point when you realise that there isn't actually much gameplay in these games, and it mostly relies on your compulsive desire to keep collecting studs to keep you entertained. At that point I found myself wondering whether I was either playing a cheap cash-in, or whether I was playing a decent Lego game and it was just that the series is designed in such a way that, by exploited our completionist desires, they can squeeze the most amount of fun out of the least amount of effort. If it's the former, it's hard to tell, and if it's the latter, I feel like I have to applaud the developers for their ingenuity.

Either way, I had fun while I was doing it, alhough I probably won't feel any reason to come back to this particular game after I've finished, as opposed to the Original Trilogy games, as my attachment to the Lego Movie was not great enough to make that a specific draw for me.

One last criticism is that I found the music to be annoying as ♥♥♥♥. I'm not a fan of the ethereal electronic soundtrack, and in the film the Everything is Awesome song is supposed to be a satirical take on bland, emotionless, corporate-built pop that is intended to be an ear-worm in the most annoying possible way. So when the developers decided to slap it all over the place in this game and have it haunt the dreams of everyone who plays it, they either missed the point of the film entirely in that regard, or they're ♥♥♥♥ing with us.

7/10

reviewText:
One of the better LEGO games.  It has a lot of fun with the premise, and it's actually kind of fun to play in a LEGO game that is entirely composed of LEGO.

The split-screen makes it a lot easier to play local co-op, though you occasionally can lose track of which side of the screen you're on, and there are rarely points where you kind of need to sit and figure out what you should be doing next.  Many scenes are quite fast-paced (the train is especially exciting).  Also, the puzzles are fun, though not too challenging.  One real nuisance as a color-blind person is that the little green studs we need to follow to get to the next instance look exactly the same as the little yellow studs.

Basically, it's a very good effort.  It follows the movie *very* closely, so be aware that you won't feel like you're encountering new objects or LEGOfications of any of your favourite movies.  Sill, my kids and I enjoyed it.

7.5/10

This is the shortest Lego game that I have played, by a long way. I really enjoyed that. The movie humour is present and very enjoyable but does not become tedious. There has been a lot of improvement in gameplay mechanics: the camera was great, the level length was just right, the free play areas were enjoyable and there were no frustrating 'jump just right' challenges. The graphics are a whole level above the graphics of other games because of the way they incorporated Lego scenery, and it's fantastic. The building minigame was too fast for me but was infrequent (unlike Lego Hobbit) and there were fewer collectibles of all sorts. Each level had 5 gold instruction manuals and one pair of pants (Honey, where are my pants?!). Gold bricks are not collected but represent your overall completion (there were 70, while Lego Marvel had 250). The variety of collectible characters is spot-on, there are relatively few, but they are all fun to play and can be unlocked easily (once you complete the appropriate level). The music within levels and in free play areas was never odious. Doing each level was fun - Lego games are often criticised for having no challenge to them, i.e., break stuff until you complete the level - but this game has the most variety (and least repetition) yet.

In short, this is a really fun game to play. There is a lot of variety and humour; the game is colourful, the graphics are great and the levels are balanced. It's a lot shorter than other Lego games, and I have thus been able to completely finish it while still enjoying it.

I'd say it's 'as good' as Lego Marvel, but there is a lot less of it. This game was released around the same time as Lego Hobbit, and this game is far better. I hope they continue with this style rather than Hobbit.

Overall, I'd give this game a ... maybe 9 out of 10? [I'm having trouble figuring out why I shouldn't give it 10, though...]

reviewText:
Compared to LEGO Marvel Super Heroes, this game feels like a gigantic step backwards. First off, this game feels like a poor movie to video game adaptation compared to the previous LEGO games like LEGO Indiana Jones or Lord of the Rings. I think the issue is that the game shackles itself to the movie and tries to follow it too closely, which breaks the whole theme of the movie which is about being creative with LEGOs. I think the game would have been much better off if it had been a prequel or parallel story of some sort that could better utilize the potential presented by the world of the LEGO movie.

This unsatisfying story is exacerbated by the rather pitiful overworld that is miniscule in comparison to other recent LEGO games like Lord of the Rings or Marvel Super Heroes. Bricksburg is all of two city blocks, the wild west is the town square, and cloud cuckoo land is two or three (small) clouds. There's a few side quests to do in these hubs, but they pale in comparison to the previously mentioned LEGO games and make this game about half as long in comparison.

To add insult to injury, the game has a surprisingly decent selection of vehicles that can be built from the treasures found in the missions but they can only be used in the bonus room (i.e. a kid's bedroom) which is basically sterile and devoid of interesting things to smash. A huge letdown from the bonus areas of the previous LEGO games.

This is all on top of the standard LEGO game bugs which required me to restart some of the missions partway through because a script wouldn't work and I would be stuck. The character creator is also fairly pitiful.

The one highlight of this game is that it adds giant mechs that can be used in some of the missions. Those would have been fun if Bricksburg had been a proper city and if the game allowed vehicles to be spawn in the hubs.

Overall I was disappointed by this LEGO game and wouldn't recommend it unless you're trying to collect all the LEGO games. Even if you liked the LEGO movie, I would say go play some of the older LEGO action games or find an old LEGO creator game instead.

The Lego Movie Game is, sadly, one of the worst Lego games to have come out for a while, on par with some of the first to be released. This game is first and foremost a movie tie-in, make no mistake. There is no original story, movie clips are used instead of in-game cutscenes, and don't expect any inivation beyond two bland mini-games.

I've loved all the Lego games so far, and I got this one with the express purpose to play as Unikitty, and on that it delivered. What it didn't deliver is that scope that we've come to expect from modern Lego games, such as sprawling open worlds, a large cast of characters, and a host of special skills that are drip-fed to you throughout. Let's look at these in more detail:

The character select screen may seem healthy, boasting 90-odd characters, but take a moment to consider who these characters are. Most are generic citizens who got mere seconds of screen time, or the mini-figured you find in the blind bags: Panda Man, Taco Tuesday Guy, and Larry the Barista are among the memorable characters you can play as, who only differ in apperance and the object they throw. The main character Emmet has not one, not three, but thirteen variations, all seperate (unlike most Lego games that stack variations of the same character on one spot) and all exactly the same, with two exceptions. Also, only the main characters have facial animations, and not even they get lip-synching when they talk.

The world is divided into four areas and a bonus zone; Bricksburg, The Old West, Cloud Coocooland and the Octan Tower. These areas consist of more or less two rooms, with missions scattered around, with no central 'hub' to begin them. Characters are bought from the character select screen, as with the newer games, but the mini-figures can also be found scattered around to buy in-person, which is completely redundant. Within 10-hours of gameplay, taking my time, I have already finished the game, bought all the characters, and bought all the red blocks, making this the shortest Lego game I've ever played (and I've played most).

The unique skills in this game are nothing mind-blowing: silver needs explosives, gold needs a laser, only construction-workers can repair, only women can be acrobatic (that's right, Batman cannot climb walls or jump around), only Master Builders can make objects, only Unikitty can use rainbow blocks, etc. etc. All very standard and mostly things we've seen before, too. Aside from Lord Buisness, who you get at the end of the game, most bonus obstacles can be cleared by the half-way point, let's say 6-hours in. It's a Lego game, so obviously you'll be going back and playing it all a second time in Free Play mode to unlock everything, but this certainly won't take anywhere near as long as the comparative colossus, Lego Batman 2.


~In summation: This is a game for people who loved the movie. You'll get to see it all again and play with characters you probably won't otherwise get to, such as Unikitty. The gameplay is exactly as you'd expect, nothing breaks the formula, and anything new is few and far between. And you'd best hope you like the soundtrack, because you'll be hearing three particular songs an awful lot. In short: It's silly, short fun, but don't expect much more for you money beyond a playable advertisment. I recommend it because it is exactly what it is: It's not great, but it's not bad either, but it most certainly IS a movie tie-in game, and should be treated as such.

The characters are modeled in what seems to be a more realistic form, and their movements match that of the movie's. Everything is good, well written and fun. The story is basically the same as the movie with a few minor changes to fit the game format. The gameplay is what you would expect, fun co-op, puzzle solving and of course, smashing everything in sight. The game has a semi-open world, that is very diverse, ranging from literal sunshines and rainbows to the desert heat of the wild west.

The most defining feature of this game is the visual style, borrowed from the movie. Most LEGO games tend to have a mix of brick built objects and non-brick objects. However, this one stands out; due to being visually represented entirely by LEGO elements (save for the bonus level). Even the character animations are decisively LEGO, differing greatly from how characters move in other LEGO games.

Unfortunately, aside from its distinct style, The LEGO Movie Videogame is just another LEGO game. It doesn’t change much from the formula and as such feels like an almost copy and paste from other previous games. There’s nothing wrong with the game, it’s just… average. There’s just not enough to make it stand out in the crowd of LEGO games. It’s not bad or below standard, just… average.

All in all, if you like LEGO games then, let’s face it, you’ve probably already bought this game. If you don’t mind the occasional LEGO game then there are better LEGO games to play. That’s not to say i don’t recommend getting this game, it still has its merit and is just as good as any LEGO game before it. So if you see it on sale, just give it a go; you won't be disappointed.

Although LEGO series is excellent, the game style is infinite, until you act something. That would mean, in some cases, the bad guys never ended their ammo, the train would go on and on forever and then accurately syncing its turn to your actions. Other than that, the game is well-designed, with a long storyline to follow. I'd recommend adding more realistic casual events that would happen naturally in real life. I rate it 5/7.

Traveller's Tales has created another fantastic entry in the LEGO videogame universe.

I have completed the entire game including the collectibles, and I must say, I am impressed. In this game the story adheres to the movie's story rather well, and uses cutscenes from the movie too, which is a nice touch.

The game follows the same formula of platforming with action sequences and linear level designs that is common in other LEGO games, although the main quest was noticably shorter than the others I have played; it took me just under 30 hours to finish the story and go back through the levels to find the collectibles and unlock every achievement. I have also noticed there are less levels and they are dragged out to be longer than usual, which I personally didn't have an issue with.

In some areas, things have changed a bit. The game's presented in a similar manner than that of the movie. The characters are modeled in what seems to be a more realistic form, and their movements match that of the movie's. In addition, almost everything is gorgeously rendered in LEGO form and is a marvel to analyze. Batman also provides some hilarious commentary at times. Fans of the movie should feel right at home.

Another brick in LEGO’s wall of games. In my opinion, The LEGO Movie Videogame is just another LEGO game; and thus has all the fun things you’d come to expect from one. Everything is good, well written and fun. The story is basically the same as the movie with a few minor changes to fit the game format. The gameplay is what you would expect, fun co-op, puzzle solving and of course, smashing everything in sight. The game has a semi-open world, that is very diverse, ranging from literal sunshines and rainbows to the desert heat of the wild west.

The most defining feature of this game is the visual style, borrowed from the movie. Most LEGO games tend to have a mix of brick built objects and non-brick objects. However, this one stands out; due to being visually represented entirely by LEGO elements (save for the bonus level). Even the character animations are decisively LEGO, differing greatly from how characters move in other LEGO games.

Unfortunately, aside from its distinct style, The LEGO Movie Videogame is just another LEGO game. It doesn’t change much from the formula and as such feels like an almost copy and paste from other previous games. There’s nothing wrong with the game, it’s just… average. There’s just not enough to make it stand out in the crowd of LEGO games. It’s not bad or below standard, just… average.

All in all, if you like LEGO games then, let’s face it, you’ve probably already bought this game. If you don’t mind the occasional LEGO game then there are better LEGO games to play. That’s not to say i don’t recommend getting this game, it still has its merit and is just as good as any LEGO game before it. So if you see it on sale, just give it a go; you won't be disappointed.

This may actually be one of my favourite lego games. I love the added features like the Building Instructions and the Pacman-style hacking mini-game which are both really fun and break up the casual gameplay which can get boring after a while. I also really like the level design which means the game is not too difficult but easy enough that I can keep on playing and is the only Lego game I've played so far that I literally couldn't put down. I'm also not a big fan of the massively open-world Lego games as I can easily get lost and I won't know where to go but this game shows where to go easily.

The only criticism I would give is that the setting menu is lacking, especially for PC users but this is present throughout all of the Lego games. The default keys are also lacking but I also have my own setup which works for me as well as a controller which I sometimes use. I also couldn't find the resolution settings in game which I think should be more obvious as I ended up playing in the wrong one for half of the game. I also came across a few bugs but they weren't game breaking and didn't require me to restart the level (like Uni-kitty getting stuck in places, but this was easily fixed by just jumping out, even thought it took a while).

Overall I do recommend this game to people who like Lego games as it does offer a slightly different formula to the original games we all know and love and I would love to see this same formula reused again (perhaps using the same characters but with a new story?)
